chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Managing short-term insomnia (less than 3 months duration)
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with short-term insomnia in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with short-term insomnia (less than 3 months duration)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Consider the need for referral to a sleep clinic or neurology if symptoms of another sleep disorder are present.
  • Address any circumstances/stressors associated with onset of insomnia.
    • Ensure comorbidities (for example anxiety or depression) are optimally managed.
  • Offer advice on sleep hygiene. 
  • Advise the person not to drive if they feel sleepy.
    • The DVLA must be informed if excessive sleepiness is having, or is likely to have, an adverse effect on driving such as:
      • Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (any severity).
      • Primary/central hypersomnias (such as narcolepsy).
      • Any other conditions or medication that may cause excessive sleepiness.
    • For more detailed guidance, see the DVLA 'At a glance' guide.
  • If sleep hygiene measures fail, daytime impairment is severe causing significant distress, and insomnia is likely to resolve soon (for example due to a short term stressor):
    • Consider a short course (3-7 days) of a non-benzodiazepine hypnotic medication (z-drug).
      • Do not prescribe hypnotics routinely — use only for short courses if acutely distressed.
      • Do not prescribe hypnotics to older people or women who are pregnant or breastfeeding.
      • For more information, see the section on Prescribing. 
  • If sleep hygiene measures fail, daytime impairment is severe causing significant distress, and insomnia is not likely to resolve soon:
    • Offer cognitive behavioural therapy for insomnia (CBT-I).
      • CBT-I typically includes behavioural interventions (such as stimulus control and sleep restriction), cognitive therapy and relaxation training and can be provided face-to-face or digitally.
    • Consider the need for adjunctive treatment with a short-term hypnotic medication (a z-drug or prolonged released melatonin if over 55 years of age).
      • Do not prescribe hypnotics routinely — use only for short courses if acutely distressed.
      • Do not prescribe hypnotics to older people or women who are pregnant or breastfeeding.
      • For more information, see the section on Prescribing. 
  • If a hypnotic is prescribed:
    • Consider the duration of action (short-acting is usually most appropriate), adverse effects, interactions and potential for dependency and abuse.
    • Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest period possible — do not continue treatment for longer than 2 weeks (preferably less than one week).
    • Inform the person that further prescriptions for hypnotics will not usually be given, ensure that the reasons for this are understood, and document this in the person's notes.
    • Do not issue further prescriptions without seeing the person again.
    • If there has been no response to the first hypnotic, do not prescribe another.
  • Provide patient information on insomnia such as:
    • Mental Health Foundation How to... sleep better.
    • NHS Insomnia.
    • Royal College of General Practitioners Top tips: insomnia in adults.
  • Arrange follow up for review (for example 2–4 weeks, dependant on the clinical situation).
    • If symptoms have not improved, reassess the person — consider CBT-I (if not already offered), alternative diagnoses and the need for referral.
  • Do not recommend over-the-counter treatments for insomnia.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of short-term insomnia are based on clinical guidance Assessment to management of adult insomnia [Alberta Medical Association, 2015] and Appropriate and cost-effective prescribing of short acting hypnotics [PrescQIPP, 2017], the British Association for Psychopharmacology consensus statement Evidence-based treatment of insomnia, parasomnias and circadian rhythm disorders: an update [Wilson, 2019], the NICE Key therapeutic topic Hypnotics [NICE, 2019a], expert opinion in review articles [Cunnington, 2016; BMJ Best Practice, 2019; Davidson, 2019; Mansfield, 2019] and the British National Formulary [BNF, 2019]. 

Advice on driving
  • Recommendations on driving are based on guidance from the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) [DVLA, 2019]. 
  • A new offence of driving with controlled drugs (including opioids and some hypnotics) above specified limits in the blood, came into force in March 2015. Further information ‘Drugs and driving: the law’ is available at www.gov.uk [NICE, 2019a]. 
  • The MHRA has issued a warning about the risk of drowsiness and reduced driving ability the next day with zolpidem [MHRA, 2014; NICE, 2019a]. 
Good sleep hygiene
  • Good sleep hygiene is widely supported as the first step in management of insomnia in current literature and clinical guidelines [Alberta Medical Association, 2015; Cunnington, 2016; PrescQIPP, 2017; NICE, 2019b; Wilson, 2019]. 
Short-term hypnotic medication and cognitive behavioural therapy for insomnia (CBT-I)
  • Recommendations are largely based on the consensus statement from the British Association for Psychopharmacology Evidence-based treatment of insomnia, parasomnias and circadian rhythm disorders: an update [Wilson, 2019], clinical guidelines from the Alberta Medical Association Assessment to management of adult insomnia [Alberta Medical Association, 2015] and the NICE Key therapeutic topic Hypnotics [NICE, 2019a]. 
  • There is wide agreement in the literature on cautious and restricted use of hypnotic medications for the treatment of severe insomnia in selected patients — in all cases, pharmacotherapy should be considered only as an adjunct to first-line management focusing on behavioural and cognitive approaches [Alberta Medical Association, 2015; PrescQIPP, 2017; Riemann, 2017; BNF, 2019; Mansfield, 2019; NICE, 2019a; Wilson, 2019]. 
  • CBT-I has been shown to be superior to pharmacotherapy in both short- and long-term management of insomnia in adults of all ages — the benefits associated with CBT-I persist on completion of treatment, unlike those associated with medication [Alberta Medical Association, 2015; Sateia, 2017]. 
  • The risks associated with the long-term use of hypnotic drugs (such as benzodiazepine and non-benzodiazepine hypnotics [z-drugs]) have been well recognised for many years and include falls, accidents, cognitive impairment, dependence and withdrawal symptoms, and an increased risk of dementia. More recent data suggest similar safety concerns with melatonin [BNF, 2019; NICE, 2019a]. 
  • Long-acting hypnotics should be avoided due the risk of residual effects the following day [PrescQIPP, 2017; BNF, 2019; Mansfield, 2019; NICE, 2019a; Wilson, 2019]. 
  • Benzodiazepines are not included in recommendations on short-term hypnotics as:
    • These are not specified in treatment algorithms in clinical guidance [Wilson, 2019]. 
    • Tolerance to benzodiazepines can be rapid and can occur within a few days of use [BNF, 2019]. 
    • Technology appraisal guidance from NICE states that there is no compelling evidence of a clinically useful difference between the 'z-drugs' and shorter-acting benzodiazepine hypnotics. In addition, there is no evidence to suggest that switching to an alternative hypnotic will be successful if a person does not respond to initial hypnotic prescribed [PrescQIPP, 2017; NICE, 2019a]. 
Avoid hypnotic medication in older people and women who are pregnant or breastfeeding
  • CBT-I has been found to be the most effective treatment for insomnia in adults of all ages — it is associated with minimal adverse effects and should be offered first-line where available [Alberta Medical Association, 2015; Wilson, 2019]. 
  • Hypnotics including the z–drugs should be avoided in the elderly due to a greater risk of ataxia and confusion, leading to falls and injury [PrescQIPP, 2017; BNF, 2019; Wilson, 2019]. 
    • A systematic review and meta-analysis looking at the association between z-drugs and fractures, falls and injuries in older adults (n=160,502) found a significant increased risk of injuries following treatment with zolpidem (OR = 2.05; CI 95%: 1.95–2.15) [Treves, 2018]. 
  • Prolonged-release melatonin is licensed as monotherapy for the short-term treatment (maximum duration 13 weeks) of primary insomnia in people aged 55 years or over. Studies indicate that melatonin given for three weeks improves sleep onset latency and sleep quality in patients over 55 years [Wilson, 2019]. 
    • Clinicians should discuss potential adverse effects (similar to other hypnotics) before prescribing [BNF, 2019; NICE, 2019a]. 
  • Hypnotics should be avoided in pregnant women where possible — specialist advice should be sought if insomnia is causing significant distress and good sleep hygiene and lifestyle measures have failed [Alberta Medical Association, 2015; BMJ Best Practice, 2019; Wilson, 2019]. 
Over-the-counter treatments
  • The Alberta Medical Association recommend avoidance of over-the-counter treatments for insomnia due to a lack of evidence and significant potential for adverse effects [Alberta Medical Association, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give regarding good sleep hygiene?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Sleep hygiene aims to increase awareness of behavioural, environmental, and temporal factors that may be detrimental or beneficial to sleep.

  • Advise the person on:
    • Normal sleep and changes in sleep patterns with age.
    • Sleep environment.
      • A comfortable sleeping environment should be maintained: not too hot, cold, noisy, or bright.
      • The bedroom should only be used for sleep and intimacy.
      • Checking or watching the clock throughout the night should be avoided.
      • Bright light (including all technology) should be minimized. ‘Blue light’ displays on electronic devices and televisions suppress melatonin production — avoid using devices for two hours before bed.
    • Regular sleep schedules including:
      • Going to bed when sleepy — avoid going to bed too early.
      • Waking up and getting out of bed at the same time every morning including weekends and after a poor night's sleep — increase exposure to bright light in the morning.
      • Avoiding napping during the day.
    • Relaxation before going to bed (for example reading a book or having a bath).
      • Relaxation exercises in the early evening may help reduce hyper-arousal. A free audio guide on progressive relaxation techniques is available on the Mental Health Foundation website.
      • Visual imagery in bed can help with racing thoughts. Information on mindfulness can be found at the Mental Health Foundation’s dedicated mindfulness website.
    • Limiting/avoidance of caffeine, nicotine and alcohol.
      • Caffeine should be avoided after midday and nicotine, alcohol, and large meals within 2 hours of bedtime.
      • Alcohol intake is a common maladaptive self-treatment strategy in insomnia which can contribute to poor sleep-maintenance.
    • Exercise.
      • Exercise should be avoided within 4 hours of bedtime but is beneficial earlier in the day.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on sleep hygiene are based on clinical guidelines Assessment to management of adult insomnia [Alberta Medical Association, 2015], European guideline for the diagnosis and treatment of insomnia [Riemann, 2017], Benzodiazepine and Z-drug deprescribing algorithm [Bruyère Research Institute Deprescribing Guidelines Research Team, 2019], the Royal College of General Practitioners Top tips: insomnia in adults [RCGP, 2019], the Mental Health Foundation How to... sleep better [Mental Health Foundation, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles [Maness, 2015; Morin, 2015; Winkelman, 2015; Mansfield, 2019]. 

  • Maintaining a regular sleep schedule and minimizing exposure to bright light (including light from televisions and phones) before bed can help increase homeostatic sleep drive — going to bed early in an attempt to gain more sleep is an unhelpful strategy [Alberta Medical Association, 2015]. 
  • Getting out of bed at the same time every morning and exposure to bright light in the morning can help strengthen the circadian rhythm of sleep regulation [Alberta Medical Association, 2015].
